text: MARK SCHULTZ (27, 180 lbs., cauliflower ears) lifts a hum sized, leather WRESTLING DUMMY from the mat to stand in f of him. He performs a series of repetitive moves - hookin one arm under the dummy's arm, then the other; one side, other. Again and again. It looks almost as if he's dancin gently with it.
Then, very fast, Mark spins quickly around behind the dum grabs it in a bear hug, arches his back, lifts and SLAMS to the mat, landing on top.
QUICK CUTS: Mark spinning, lifting and slamming the dummy first one way, then the other - first one hold, then anot SLAM. SLAM. SLAM. SLAM. SLAM - over and over and over aga

Mark pulls his beat-up car into a space in the parking lo this nondescript, 1960s-era suburban brick-facade school. He's freshly showered, wears a short-sleeve dress shirt, on tie, slacks. He reaches behind the front seat and pull out a battered BROWN VINYL BRIEFCASE.
Mark waits alone in a chair he's much too big for, his br vinyl briefcase on his lap. A portrait of President Reaga hangs on the painted cinder block wall. A clock ticks.
Mark's on stage. An audience of 4th, 5th and 6th graders.
Why do I do it? Why do I push myself to my limits - of pain, of exhaustion - every day of my life? Why do I wake up every morning and make the commitment? Why do I do it? 2.
The students are open-mouthed - they have no idea what to make of him. Mark's not being willfully over-the-top with these kids. This is just what's on his mind. All the time
In 13 months - if I train right, if I push myself - I'll be going to Seoul - that's a city in South Korea. Does anyone know why? Because that's where the Olympic games are.
Mark reaches into the briefcase at his feet and pulls out RIBBON with a MEDAL dangling from it.
Does anyone know what this is?
As a couple of kids start to raise their hands --

Olympic gold medal. I won it three years ago at the `84 Games in Los Angeles. My brother, Dave Schultz - my best friend, my older brother, my best friend - won one too, just 23 hours and 16 minutes before I did. That's unprecedented - two brothers winning at the same Olympics.

Would you like me to win another one? Would you like me to win another gold medal - for us, for America? Would you like to see me and my big brother - Dave Schultz - both win gold medals? Who here wants to see the two brothers win again?
Silence. A couple of the kids tentatively raise their han The rest are completely frozen.
Well we're going to give it absolutely everything we've got.
A SCHOOL SECRETARY writes out a check as Mark stands in f of the desk, placing his medal back in his briefcase. 3.
Twenty... and... no one-hundreds...
She tears off the check and hands it to Mark. He takes th check, holds out to her a SIGNED 8x10 PHOTO of himself wi his arms raised, in a USA WRESTLING SINGLET just after winning his Olympic gold.
And this is for the trophy case.
I'm sorry?... For what?
For the trophy case.
With the trophies.
It's an elementary school.
As Mark holds out the photo, WE HEAR:
Can I take your order?
A long-haired, greasy KID with the very beginnings of a mustache takes Mark's order. Mark looks up at the menu si
I'll have a # 4.
# 4. Anything to drink?
No. Can I get extra meat on that?
65 cents.
What are you talking about?
Extra meat costs extra. 4.
Where's it say that?
I don't know. I just know I'm supposed to charge extra for extra meat.
I always get extra meat. Every time I come here.
It's extra for extra meat. They told me. 65 cents.

text: Mark sits in his car, eating his sandwich - no enjoyment, just fueling himself. His RADIO plays a commercial.

DAVE SCHULTZ (31, bearded, intelligent, 163 lbs., strong, fierce, but calm), Head Coach of U of W wrestling, stands the wrestling mat speaking VERY QUIETLY with 3 or 4 selec WRESTLERS from the team. We can't quite hear what Dave is saying to them, but we can sense immediately the reverenc and deep respect they have for Dave - one of the country' top wrestlers and great coaches.
The scene gives off the feeling one might have watching a horse whisperer with a small group of stallions. Whatever he's saying, they are calmed by him, pay absolute attenti will do whatever he asks.

A cheaply built 70s-era structure, where Mark inhabits tw small rooms with a cheap kitchenette built into the wall one of them. A particle-board BOOKCASE houses a little SH of Mark's medals - and PHOTOS of him and Dave.
Mark retrieves his briefcase from inside the garbage bag extracts his GOLD MEDAL. 5.
He replaces it in the PLASTIC DISPLAY CASE on the top she next to the photo of him and Dave smiling with their gold medals around their necks.
Mark dumps a package of TOP RAMEN NOODLES into boiling wa And another package. And another.
Mark sits on his one metal FOLDING CHAIR, at his table, eating his bowl of noodles. Moths tap against the window.
Mark, in just boxer shorts, crosses off another day on hi wall calendar. 427 days to Seoul. He looks around, then d to the floor and starts a monstrous number of push-ups.
Mark runs hard past warehouses and auto repair outlets.

location: FIELD AND HILL NEXT TO CAR DEMOLITION YARD

text: Mark runs through knee-high weeds dragging a CAR TIRE attached to a rope behind him. He reaches a hill and head straight up, dragging the tire all the way -
Coach Teller? This is Mark Schultz--
An ink-stained directory of Wisconsin Public Schools lies open on the kitchen table.
I won a freestyle wrestling gold medal at the `84 Olympics.

Mark, the phone tucked against his shoulder, slips a BLAN TAPE into a cheap VCR. He slides a HAND-LABELED TAPE into second VCR, wired to the first. We can read the label: "T MARK SCHULTZ WRESTLING CLINIC." He starts making a copy.
I'm arranging a clinic in your area next weekend, and I wanted to invite you and some of your wrestlers to join...
That's Dave, my brother. I wrestle at 180... No, he won't be there, just me... Okay - well, good luck with your season, coach.
On the screen is a montage of highlights from Mark's care take downs, pins. He's an animal - powerful, aggressive.
Yes, there's a small fee.
On the screen, Mark wrestles Resit Karabajak, a Turkish wrestler, in his first round match at the `84 Olympics.
A unique, character-building opportunity for young wrestlers.... Yes, a small fee...
Mark throws Karabajak to the mat. Pins him. Walks away, a raised. Crowd cheers. Karabajak's on the mat, hurt. 7.
Dave's my brother...
On screen, Mark does a back flip.
Olympic Champion...
Mark does a back flip.
Dave's my brother...
Mark's holds the phone on his lap, just watching himself the screen, wrestling... winning... match after match...

Mark's outside at the second floor railing of this two-st stucco building, looking out over the bleak landscape: a 11, an Auto-Zone. He eats a hard-boiled egg. He watches a pull into the lot below. Dave gets out, looks up.
Where were you today?
Dave fills two mismatched glasses with tap water from the faucet.
How far'd you run? Ten?
Mark's on the tattered couch. He shrugs, though we should that he loves the fact that Dave is concerned about him.
More than ten? Dragging weight the whole way? (Dave turns off the water) You're a sick fuck, you know that?
Dave turns to look at Mark, sitting in the bare living ro 8.
Place is looking good, by the way. I like what you've done with it.
Dave notices the Public Schools Directory on the table.
You setting up clinics?
Talked to some coaches.
Dave comes toward Mark, handing off a water glass, draggi the folding chair over to sit across from him.
I hope you don't have anything booked for Saturday.
Why?
I need a favor. This school called me months ago to do a gig but now I can't. Nancy's got a thing all day so I gotta watch the kids. You free?
I'll check.
He goes into the bedroom, looks at the calendar. There's NOTHING WRITTEN DOWN for any of the days.
You said Saturday or Sunday?
Saturday.
Saturday could work.
He comes back in.
Good. Thank you.
Dave looks at the BACK OF HIS HAND, where he's written do name and phone number in MARKER. He grabs one of Mark's V labels and a pen and writes the information. 9.
Coach Vinson, Radnor High. I'll let him know you'll call tomorrow.
He peels off the label and slaps it on Mark's leg.
And Mark. Please come back to the gym. You don't have to do anything with the team. Just train with me.
Mark's just looking at his older brother.
I need you there. Stay focused on what's important. For both of us. Seoul's the goal.
Beat. Beat. Then, Mark nods at his brother.
Seoul's the goal.
Seven HIGH SCHOOL BOYS plus a couple of PRE-TEENS, all in wrestling gear, sit on the mat in front of Mark. He seems manic, evangelical, not tuned into his audience.

The minute you step on the mat, you are exactly who you are. You can't hide. You can't pretend you trained harder than you did, you want it more than you do. My brother Dave and me care about this more than we care about anything. The difference between the number one guy in the world and the number four guy is paper thin. The one who wins is the one who wants it more, who's willing to sacrifice, who can take the pain. I can take the pain. My brother Dave can take the pain. Can you take the pain?
Blank looks from the teenage wrestlers. Mark gestures to table set up near the door, on which is his OPEN BRIEFCAS with a stack of TAPES. 10.
I talk about all this in my instructional videotape - which you can purchase at the end of the day for a nominal fee.
Mark exits the locker room in his wrestling gear, heading the MATS.
Dave's in his wrestling gear, on the far side of the gym, talking with TWO MIDDLE-AGED MEN in blazers with USA WRESTLING INSIGNIA. Mark walks onto the mat, waits for hi
Dave and the two men see Mark, WAVE to him - but Mark pretends not to notice, busies himself loosening his wris hands, neck. Dave walks over to him.
You remember Fred Cole from USA Wrestling.
The men walk up behind Dave.
Hey there, Mark, how you been?
Mark sort of nods, but doesn't really respond.
(beat, then turns to Dave) All right, Dave. Let us know if we can count on you. We'll talk soon.
Dave nods. They walk away. Then Dave turns back to Mark.
You been calling me and hanging up?
(adjusting his knee brace) No. What do you mean?
Mark doesn't answer, just stands looking at him. For seve seconds, they look at each other. Then, slowly at first:
They start to circle each other. We sense immediately the differences: Dave's hunched and not very muscular physiqu belies his quickness and enormous strength. 11.
Mark's defining characteristic is brute force. A weight c heavier than Dave, he can NEVER SEEM TO BEAT HIS OLDER BROTHER.
The wrestling becomes intense and violent - Mark's head s into Dave's nose, drawing BLOOD. This only energizes Dave who slams Mark to the mat - dripping blood onto him.
VARIOUS SHOTS of the increasingly brutal match, ending wi
Dave rides Mark, who's on his stomach, flattened and spla grappling for a hold. Mark glances up to SEE: The USA Wrestling men WATCHING from near the door.
Mark looks away, gritting his teeth, but Dave's gotten hi hold. As Dave TURNS and slams the bigger Mark -
Mark looks out the window. Silence. They sit there, both bruised and bloodied.
Sorry about your nose.
No, you're not.
Come by the house, have dinner with me and Nance and the kids.
Mark's still looking out the window. He speaks quietly -
You win a gold medal for them. And still. Nothing. No respect.
He reaches for the door handle.
Hey. Gimme a hug.

Dave reaches for his arm, and Mark folds automatically in his older brother, puts his head on his chest. Dave embra him for several long moments - it's like a father and his young child. Then Dave smacks him on the back of the neck
Same time tomorrow. 12.
Mark nods, gets out of the car and walks away.
Mark presses PLAY on his answering machine. Hang-ups and TONES.
Mark examines his bruised face in the mirror, wiping away blood - some of it his, some his brother's.
Mark's at the refrigerator, cracking ice cube trays into plastic 7-11 shopping bag. The PHONE RINGS. He picks up -
Yah.
A man's voice is heard. It sounds like long distance.
May I please speak with Mr. Mark Schultz?
It's Mark.
I'm sorry to call you at night, but Mr. du Pont was anxious that I get in touch with you.
Okay...
He asked that you please consider taking a day off from your training to come out to Foxcatcher Farms so you men can meet face to face.
Who do you work for again? 13.
John E. du Pont of the du Pont family of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania.
You may also know of him in connection with his support of the Villanova wrestling program.
What does he want to talk about?
Mr. du Pont requested that I contact you to set up a meeting. He'd like to bring you out to Pennsylvania.
Uh-huh.
If I may I'd like to make travel arrangements for you, Mr. Schultz.
Mark's holding the ice cube tray, alone in his dingy kitc
Mr. Schultz?
BRANDON (20s, post-prep school, jacket/tie) waits for Mar
Mr. Schultz, I'm Brandon. Welcome to Philadelphia.

Mark watches out the clear Plexi as the Pennsylvania countryside spreads out below him. He and Brandon and the pilot (LARRY - 50s, aviator glasses, Air Cavalry patch on jacket) all wear RADIO MIC HEADSETS. 14.
Mr. du Pont would have flown you himself, but he was asked at the last minute for tactical assistance by the Newtown Square Police Department.
Mark has no idea what that means, but nods his head.
He should be back at the estate by the time we get there.
Larry BANKS the plane steeply on Mark's side so Mark has unobstructed view of the ground.
Valley Forge below you.
They speed over the historic site - wide fields, the memo arch, wood fences, the old stone house.
The du Pont family's supplied American armed forces with gunpowder since the beginning. (as Larry heads south) Foxcatcher in three minutes.
A MARE and FOAL run away as the helicopter descends towar the Big House - a huge Georgian brick home in the middle 800 acres of fields and woods and outbuildings.
Brandon leads Mark down a carpeted hallway.
They enter. It's at once grandly elegant and musty. 15.
Feel free to look around the library. Mr. du Pont will be up shortly.

Shuts the door behind him. Mark's never been in a room li this - oil paintings of du Pont ancestors; foxhounds, hor hunts. Leather-bound books share space with framed OLD ST and antique (and not so antique) PISTOLS. Framed PHOTOS o the same man (JOHN DU PONT - 50, thin, beak-nosed, blond- hair) with Presidents Ford, Nixon, Reagan... Henry Kissin
Mark's standing, gazing at the photos, when the door open revealing JOHN DU PONT, a police-issue HOLSTER dangling f one hand. He stops and breathlessly regards Mark.
You're actually here.
Oh. Yes, sir.
In my study.
(no idea what to say) They said it was the library.
It is.
Du Pont puts the holster onto a chair. Holds out his hand
John du Pont.
Mark Sch --

- I know who you are - I've watched your Olympic victory enough times to know exactly who you are, every inch of you. Please, put your bag down, make yourself comfortable, sit, make yourself at home -

(You quickly realize that du Pont can be voluble and charming, but the more time you spend with him, the more see what an effort this is for him - how essentially uncomfortable he is in his own skin.... Also, he just mig have snorted a tiny bit of coke before he came in.) 16.
Mark sits. Du Pont settles in, sits facing him - focused entirely on Mark. He speaks intimately, sincerely

I watched the video of your Olympic run again last night. After you broke the arm of the Turk - after they disqualified you, handed you a loss - after they put an extra official on you to watch your holds - all of which were legal - after all that you rack up seven straight wins to take the medal. For your country. Thrilling. Thrilling. Inspiring. Take the gold medal.
Mark can't recall when he's received this kind of attenti
Thank you, sir. I'm proud of that day.
You should be. I'm proud of that day. I'm proud of you on that day. Your parents must be enormously proud.
(after a moment) To be perfectly honest, we don't often talk.
Du Pont nods, hoping Mark might say more. When he doesn't
I want to tell you how much I appreciate your coming here. I know it cuts into your training. I imagine that's every day for you?
Yes sir, it is.
Strength training in the morning? Upper body regimen - muscle tone - building up the muscle tone - across the upper body. In the morning? 17.
Oh. Well. I take the mornings on my own - as you said, strength training, endurance - then I meet up with my brother - you know Dave Schultz - ?
Of course, of course, yes, I know him. I mean, not personally, but yes, of course, I do know him.
- I meet up with him at the U-W gym, we work out whatever free time we can grab between team practice.
University of Wisconsin.
Yes sir.
Where you both coach.
Mark NODS vaguely.
And they provide you with everything you need?
Beat.
Pretty much.
A moment as du Pont watches Mark.
I'd like to see you win this upcoming tournament -
- Thank you -
- I'd like to help you win this upcoming tournament. It's a big one, yes?
It's the world championship. 18.
Du Pont nods.
Why do you do it, Mark?
Mark just looks at him, unsure what he's being asked.
Why?
(simply no other reason) I want to be the best in the world.
I want you to be the best in the world. I want this country to be the best in the world.
May I speak frankly?
Mark nods... of course.
I'm concerned. I'm concerned by what I see in these Unites States. Athletes labor to bring honor to America, and America fails to honor that labor. Fails to honor it and fails to support it.
Mark's staring at du Pont intently.
When did you win your first match?
I started kind of late - high school sophomore.
Du Pont waits, listening...

I was... well, truthfully, I was... kind of lost. And I got into it `cause my brother was wrestling. He convinced me to give it a try. I never told him this, but I was scared of losing in front of him. So of course my first match I get put up against a kid two years older. Dave was helping coach from my corner... and at the end, when the ref raised my hand...
there was my brother, he was running towards me - screaming - laughing - he lifted me up --
Mark stops - face flushed - tries to stop himself from getting CHOKED UP. After a few moments, he speaks quietly
It's always been his sport. He let me inside. I'm just lucky to be very very good at it.
You won that match. Not him.
Du Pont and Mark walk the last few steps of a huge lawn u an OLD FIELD HOUSE in the final stages of renovation. Du opens the door. They walk into a gleaming new GYM.
Four pristine WRESTLING MATS are spread out on the floor. Through a doorway on the far end we can glimpse a WEIGHT with new nautilus and stationary bikes and free weights.
The U.S. Olympic Committee refuses to recognize that training for international competition is a full time job. Why is that? Why is that? (looks at Mark) I want you all to have a home.
VARIOUS SHOTS of the vast historic site - monuments and fences and stone house headquarters.
I wish every American could come here and see for themselves. See the price of freedom. It's not free at all. 20.
Mark stands next to John on a ridge over the CEMETERY fie Du Pont's front leg is poised on a large rock, as if he's General surveying all that has been conquered. His black Mercury is parked nearby.
The sacrifices of the troops that first long winter remind me of what you athletes go through.
Silence as they look out over the national park.
I'm gratified my family could play a small part in the history here.
Then du Pont speaks, as much to Mark as to himself -
We can't choose the family we're born to. But we can make our own.
I can't think of anyone I'd rather build a team with. (turns to Mark) You name your price.
A plane takes off on the runway.
CLOSE UP on Mark's face, looking at himself in the mirror Studying his own face. Then he erupts in a PRIMAL SCREAM.

CLOSE UP on the face of a SIX-YEAR OLD BOY, CRYING - terrified. ALEXANDER, Dave's son. He's mid-way up a tall tree and scared to go any higher. Dave is a couple of branches above him. He looks down at Alexander, patiently waiting for the boy to stop crying. Finally, ALEX stops. 21.
You ready?
Beat. The boy nods. They climb higher.
Mark rides in the back of a cab. As he nears Dave's house SEE Nancy tapping a beer keg in the side yard. Dave and A sit in the TOP OF THE TREE, watching Mark arrive.
Lots of U of W wrestlers, coaches, wives, girlfriends, ki Dave's at the BBQ, carving a huge roast on a spit with a CARVING KNIFE. Mark's talking to him -
25 thousand a year. He said name your price and I said the highest price that came into my head. We'd get to hand-pick our own team, wrestlers we want to work with -
Who you gonna train with?
No - I mean... when I say we, I mean - you and me... could choose a team. Together.
What does du Pont get out of it?

As soon as you meet him you'll understand. He sees what we're after. He cares about America - old family, basically paid for the Revolutionary War - he gets it. He wants to help us win, help restore our pride.
My pride is fine. 22.
No, not.... This country's pride.
Dave just looks at him, silent.

Dave - this is it. This is what we've wanted our whole lives - just to train - you and me - not to have to deal with USA Wrestling, or Harper and his corrupt university program - not to have to think about anybody else...
Nancy has wandered over, Danielle on her hip.
- What're you guys talking about?
I'm speaking to my brother, that okay with you?
Nancy and Dave share a glance. Then Nancy turns to walk a
Always good to see you, Mark. (as she walks away) Please, eat our food, shit on our lawn. Enjoy yourself...
The brothers are silent for a long moment until she's gon
Why does she...
He trails off. Then, a bit desperate -
The deer hunting on his farm's supposed to be amazing...
Dave speaks gently.
I got a good thing going here. I got a contract. Nancy's happy, Alex likes his school...
The reality starts to hit Mark that he may be doing this alone, without his older brother. He's shell-shocked.
The Worlds are sixty days away. 23.
Tell me your plan. Who you gonna train with?

Du Pont's taking his money out of the Villanova program. They'll pull the plug on that. So. Dan Bane could come. I - I guess Dan Bane. (beat, then, very quietly) I don't know how to do this without you.
Do what?
The answer is "everything" -- but Mark just shakes his he
It sounds like an opportunity.
Does it?
I think you could make something of it.
Do you?
A spot's always open for you if you decide to come.
Thank you.
Dave steps forward and holds out his arms -
Congrats, little brother.
Mark steps into his brother's arms, folding into him, hea his chest, holding on for dear life. Nancy looks over.
Mark packs his apartment - trashing just about everything tossing it in the dumpster - stuffing the few essentials his AMC GREMLIN.
Mark drives across Ohio.
Mark gets gas. The attendant - clearly a HIGH SCHOOL WRES - shakes his hand.
Mark pulls onto the estate grounds.
Mark rings the doorbell. No answer. He goes to ring it ag and the door is opened by a UNIFORMED MAID.
Hi. I'm Mark Schultz.
Silence. That means nothing to her.
I'm here to see John du Pont?
Is Mr. du Pont expecting you?
Yeah. Well - not today exactly, but, yes. This week. Sometime.
Just a moment, please. 25.
In the meantime can I use the -
She SHUTS the door, leaving him outside. He turns and loo out over the VAST LAWN of the estate. Far off, it's being mowed by a gardener.
(opening the door) Please.
They walk just a few feet and she gestures toward a door.
Is he? He's in there?
The washroom.
Floral wallpaper, gold fixtures and faucet. Mark pisses - mouth open, eyes half shut. He flushes.

He looks at a dish holding little pastel horseshoes. Soap picks one up, smells it. Washes his hands - monstrous wit the tiny soap. He wipes his hands on his pants, avoiding neatly hung towelettes. He opens the door.
Mr. Beck will see you now.
Mark doesn't know who Mr. Beck is.
Mark is let into a large third floor office with a big de wood filing cabinets, LAW BOOKS lining the bookshelves.
STAN BECK (mid-forties, no-nonsense, suit and tie) rises behind the desk as Mark enters. 26.
Come in, sit down.
Thanks.
Thank you, Rosie.
You're welcome, Mr. Beck.
She exits, closing the door behind her.
Okay. Okay. So. Mark Schultz, correct?
Yes.
(opens a folder, writing)
That's right.
Mark just looks at him. Beat. Then he nods.
All right. Mark. I manage affairs for Mr. du Pont. Look after his interests. If you have a problem, you come to me. If Mr. Du Pont has a problem, I'll come to you. Okay?
Sounds okay.
Let's talk about what you're doing here. I'd like to make sure we all understand each other. Does that sound like a good policy to you?
That could be a good policy. 27.

Good. I think so, too. First thing I can tell you is that Mr. du Pont is very happy he can help you with your goals. But I want to make sure you're aware of what's expected. It's not a free ride. In exchange for the guest house, the more than substantial salary, the privilege of training at Foxcatcher Farms, Mr. du Pont expects results. Understood?
Yes.
I'm sure you can appreciate that.
Of course.
That goes for every wrestler.
I've actually got suggestions for about half the roster.
He pulls a creased, folded piece of paper from his pocket
What about the other half?
I've been making phone calls.
I'll take a look at that when you've finished. All right. Now.
Stan takes out a form, writes on it as Mark puts away lis
Your age?
Twenty-seven.
Education? 28.
Oklahoma University.
Undergraduate?
Yes.
You graduated?
Yes.
Do you own any property?
No.
Are your parents still married?
No.
How old were you when they separated?
Two.
Have you ever been accused of a crime?
No.
The DOOR OPENS and John du Pont pokes his head in. Mark STANDS, relieved to see him finally --
Mr. du Pont.
Du Pont seems surprised to see Mark. He stays in the door waves slightly.
Ah. Hello. You've arrived. 29.
Yes sir, I drove straight down.
It's a little odd that du Pont doesn't enter - he seems nervous. He looks at Stan. Stan hands him a sheet of pape
Tonight's speech. All set.
John takes the paper and glances at it. Then -
They're setting him up in the chalet?
Yes, sir.
Excellent bed. Firm mattress.
Good for the lower back.
Great.
All right.
All right. Thank you, sir.
And du Pont's gone, closing the door behind him. Beat.
Shall we finish this?
Mark sits.
Have you ever been sued?
No.
Have you ever initiated a lawsuit?
Brandon walks with Mark. They've come far, across the hug side yard - the Big House looks small behind them.
Mark can see HORSE STABLES that let out onto a huge fence track with a grass infield. Stable hands are putting seve thoroughbred horses through their paces.
(re the horses) They're Mrs. du Pont's. We all just keep our distance.
They enter the WOODS. Just inside the trees is THE CHALET European style wooden guest house that is now Mark's home
I didn't realize he was married.
Mr. du Pont? He's not. Mrs. du Pont's his mother.

Brandon lets Mark in the door, turns on the lights in the living room, in the kitchen, goes to the bedroom. It's decorated like a ski chalet. Brandon walks back from the bedroom, holding KEYS out to Mark-
Utilities are paid for - gas, electric. Refrigerator's stocked for now, but in the future you're responsible for feeding yourself. Unless of course you get invited to the Big House for dinner.
Mark, still standing in the entry-way, accepts the keys.
Someone will bring your car around. Anything else you need?
Has he always lived with his mother?
Mr. du Pont? I think so. 31.
Brandon leaves. Mark stands still for a long time, gazing his new home - including some of the oddities, like the P BEAR SKIN RUG (with HEAD ON) which is draped over the sof

Mark (in tank-top undershirt) tapes up PHOTOS of himself Dave. The POLAR BEAR HEAD on the rug gazes blankly at him KNOCK on the living room window. It's John du Pont, who points toward the front door.
Mark opens the door. John's standing on the little porch, wearing a tux, holding a BOOK and a SMALL BOX.
Mr. du Pont, I want to thank you
Du Pont holds up a finger. Mark STOPS. Du Pont whispers -
You hear that?
Mark listens, shakes his head. Du Pont holds up his finge again - and then we HEAR it: a faint HOOTING from the woo
Barred owl -
He hands Mark the small box he's holding. Inside is a ver small set of BINOCULARS.
When you spot one, you'll see with each hoot there's a white flash in his collar. His throat swells, and he reveals to you the lighter feathers he keeps hidden underneath.
He hands Mark the BOOK: "South Pacific Birds" by John Eleuthere du Pont.
It's from ten years ago, but I thought you might find it interesting. 32.
You wrote this?
I did.
Mark seems genuinely touched and impressed.
Thank you. Do you want to come in?
No no -
- The fridge is full - you probably know better than me what's in there-
- No. You need your rest. You need to get started bright and early.
Du Pont hold up his own set of binoculars.
- I had a wonderful night a few years back when I spotted all eight Northeast species. Right here on the farm.
What do we have - two months to the Worlds?
Not even. 54 days.
